outside of those parameters.
The ALEUS facility at 32500 N 51st Ave utilizes an Emergency Action Plan, Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), and Emergency Action Plan Training to ensure personnel are trained to identify and respond to accident and emergency situations.
Actual response to an emergency would be by the City of Phoenix Fire Department.
The ALEUS plant at 32500 N 51st Ave would respond to accidental releases from the covered process by
-	Notification of all persons on site
-	Notification of contiguous industrial site by telephone
-	Notification of local fire department by telephone
-	Stopping equipment and isolating any equipment which may leak flammable gases
-	Isolation of bulk tank via remote emergency stop
-	Evacuation of the area
-	Coordination with the local fire department and LEPC.

recommended maintenance / integrity inspections are
followed.
Process hazard analysis by HAZOP has been used to identify potential concerns and ensure mitigation to low levels of risk per
ALEUS policy.
When contractors are used on the site, rigorous selection and training specific to the site is performed to ensure potential
hazards of contractors are mitigated.
A hot work program in conjunction with a Safe Work Permit system is used to lower risk from hot work. A Management of
Change process is used for any alterations to the system.
An incident investigation process applied at multiple facilities in different geographic areas facilitates the timely review of all
similar systems operated by Air Liquide ensuring identified risks are mitigated.
All employees are trained on the sites emergency action plan, which includes the assistance of the local fire department and
the LEPC.
Audits of the system are conducted periodically and a pre-startup review occurs prior to startup after any significant change.
This facility complies with the EPA accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes
and regulations. The covered bulk tanks were designed / installed and is maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and
Washington state law.
In addition, the Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP (ALEUS) facility at 32500 N 51st Ave utilizes safety equipment such as:
-	Gauges and internal piping to ensure the bulk tanks are operated at or below maximum allowable working pressure capacity
-	Overpressure relief valves for pressure vessels per ASME code
-	Fail-closed emergency shut-off valves
-	Relief valves on compressor piping
-	Process alarms and interlocks in the downstream processes, sensitive to: flows, steam to carbon ratios, pressures,
temperatures, and levels
-	Manual emergency shutdown system
-	Nearby water cannons (commonly called monitors)
-	Manual isolation valves to safeguard the system, ensure a safe range of operation and actively mitigate ev

The ALEUS operation at 32500 N 51st Ave  Phoenix, AZ 85086 utilizes the following accidental release prevention and emergency response
policies at the stationary source:
-	Systems are designed by engineers
-	Standard operating procedures to ensure the facility is operated as designed
-	Management of change to ensure the covered process is not altered without a safety review
-	Operator training to ensure correct operating procedure (SOP)
-	Operator training to ensure emergency response including shutting down systems to limit the impact of potential release
-	Enforcement of area electrical classification and conforming equipment
-	Safety training for all personnel on site
THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:
The substance which triggers 40 CFR 68 compliance is hydrogen, stored in both liquid and gas form. The primary function of
the Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP (ALEUS) facility at 32500 N 51st Ave is to supply bulk gasses to our customer via pipeline
on a 24 hour, 365-day basis. Bulk gasses other than hydrogen are inert and non-regulated by this program (Helium and CO2).
The facility manufactures hydrogen by process of catalytic reformation. During the process of manufacturing hydrogen,
methane is combined with steam at high temperatures in a two-phase reaction to generate hydrogen and water. Hydrogen is
stored in liquid form in stationary bulk tanks and transported in gaseous form via pipeline to the on-site customer.
The ALEUS stationary source located at 32500 N 51st Ave, includes two 25,000 US gallon vacuum-insulated cryogenic, horizontal) tanks of liquefied hydrogen and small amounts of hydrogen within the process vessels and piping.
The chemical specific accidental release and accident prevention steps are those used to mitigate risk from flammable gases.
Employees are consulted and trained on the process using standard operating procedures. The equipment was designed by
engineers. Documentation pertaining to the design of the process and
